newsitem.title: USA: U.S. 10-yr note draws moderate demand at auction.
newsitem.headline: U.S. 10-yr note draws moderate demand at auction.

text.p: The $10 billion in new 10-year notes that the U.S. Treasury sold on Tuesday attracted a little less demand than expected as buyers showed themselves to be a bit wary of current price levels, analysts said.
"It was a bit weaker than what was expected," said Kevin Flanagan, first vice president and money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
The auction produced an average yield of 6.502 percent, the lowest for a 10-year auction since February 7, when the average yield was 5.649 percent.
The spread between the high and average yields, known as the tail, was one basis point.
The bid-to-cover ratio, the value of bids received over the value of securities sold, was 2.34 to one.

That was stronger than the last 10-year note auction on August 7 when the bid-to-cover ratio was 2.22 to one, but less than the the bid-to-cover ratio of 2.66 to one at the last off-cycle 10-year note auction on July 9.
Non-competitive bids totaled a tepid $284 million, down from $385 million at each of the two previous 10-year note sales.
Flanagan said the U.S. Treasury market had traded up going into the auction "in response to the notion that there was good bidding here" for the 10-year notes.
But demand did not quite live up to expectations.

"The cover was average, nothing to write home about. And the non-comp bid was the lowest since August 1986," Flanagan said. He said prices, now near the high end of their six-month ranges, may just have made investors feel a little wary.
"The market had rallied since Friday and a lot of good news had been factored in," Flanagan said. "Investors felt a little bit apprehensive about coming in at these levels."

"Early today, people were saying (the average yield) was going to be 6.53 or 6.54," said Matthew Alexy, chief markets strategist at CS First Boston Corp. "No one really got completely shut out, given that it traded well going into the one o'clock deadline.

"At the same time, we're at levels here that make some sense given the (employment) data that we saw, but by the same token you have a lot of risk going into the next big event which of course is the inflation data," said Alexy.
Alexy said the risk is chiefly the September Consumer Price Index (CPI) due next Wednesday, October 16, rather than to the Producer Price Index (PPI) due this Friday, October 11.
"I like the market here," said Alexy, "but again, there's a lot of discussion."
The yield on the new Treasury 10-year notes was 6.5075 percent in when-issued, mid-afternoon trade.
